Which of the traces could have been produced by the mains electricity supply?
parts.explanationPrompt: Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: It is **alternating** / a.c. / it changes **direction** / p.d. (accept: because B and C are d.c.)

parts.text: The picture shows two adaptors being used to plug five electrical appliances into the same socket. Explain why it is dangerous to have all five appliances switched on and working at the same time.
markScheme: 1 mark: Too much **current** flows through the socket / socket is **overloaded**
1 mark: The wiring / socket gets **hot** / risk of **fire**

parts.text: RCCBs operate by detecting a difference in the current between two wires. Complete the sentence. Choose the correct answer from the box.

An RCCB contains an iron rocker and a coil. A student investigated how the force of attraction, between a coil and an iron rocker, varies with the current in the coil. She supported a coil vertically and connected it in an electrical circuit, part of which is shown in the figure below. She put a small mass on the end of the rocker and increased the current in the coil until the rocker balanced. She repeated the procedure for different masses.

Table 1 shows some of her results.

State two extra components that must have been included in the circuit in the figure above to allow the data in the table to be collected. Give reasons for your answers.

tables.caption: Mass and current results
headers: Current needed for the rocker to balance in amps

markScheme: 1 mark: **Variable resistor** (accept: variable power supply / switch)
1 mark: To **vary** the current (accept: to control the current / to stop apparatus getting hot / to reset equipment)

parts.text: A teacher said that the values of current were too high to be safe. Suggest two changes that would allow lower values of current to be used in this investigation.
markScheme: 1 mark: **More turns** on the coil / use an **iron core** in the coil / move the mass **closer to the pivot** / reduce the **gap** between the coil and rocker

questions.title: Oscilloscope traces, series and parallel lamps
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: Figure 1 shows the oscilloscope trace an alternating current (a.c.) electricity supply produces. One vertical division on the oscilloscope screen represents 5 volts. Calculate the peak potential difference of the electricity supply.
Complete the sentence. Choose the answer from the box.

parts.text: Figure 2 shows how two lamps may be connected in series or in parallel to the 230 volt mains electricity supply. Calculate the potential difference across each lamp when the lamps are connected in series. The lamps are identical.
Two identical lamps are connected in parallel to the 230 volt mains electricity supply. What is the potential difference across each lamp?
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: B - 230 V (in parallel, each lamp gets the full supply voltage)

parts.text: Give one advantage of connecting the lamps in parallel instead of in series.
markScheme: 1 mark: If one goes out the other still works / lamps are **brighter** / **power** output is greater / can be switched **independently**

parts.text: Figure 3 shows the light fitting used to connect a filament light bulb to the mains electricity supply. The light fitting does not have an earth wire connected. Explain why the light fitting is safe to use.
markScheme: 1 mark: Plastic is an **insulator** (accept: the light fitting is **double insulated**)

parts.text: A fuse can be used to protect an electrical circuit. Name a different device that can also be used to protect an electrical circuit.
markScheme: 1 mark: **(Residual current) circuit breaker** / RCCB / MCB

questions.title: Two-way switches and lamp fitting safety
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: The diagram shows an electric circuit used in a dolls' house. The switches are 2-way switches; this means that each switch has a connecting wire that can be in one of two positions. With the connecting wire in each switch in the position shown in the diagram, the lamp is off. Why?
markScheme: 1 mark: The **circuit is not complete** / circuit is **broken** / switches are **open**

parts.text: When switched on, the lamp in a dolls' house circuit has a resistance of 18 Ω and draws a current of 0.5 A from the power supply. Use the equation: potential difference = current × resistance. Calculate the potential difference of the power supply.
A second, identical lamp (resistance 18 Ω) is added to the dolls' house circuit. The two lamps are joined in series. Calculate the total resistance of the two lamps.

Two-way switch circuits are used in real houses, with one switch at the top of the stairs and another at the bottom. What is the advantage of using this circuit rather than a simple circuit with only one switch?
markScheme: 1 mark: Can be switched **on or off** from the **top or bottom** of the stairs

parts.text: The diagram shows an old type of metal lamp fitting. The cable has been connected to the lamp fitting in a way that makes the lamp fitting unsafe. What is the possible risk to someone touching the lamp fitting while the lamp is switched on?
What should be done to make an unsafe metal lamp fitting safe to use?
Complete the sentence. Choose the correct answer from the box.

parts.text: The diagram shows a three-pin plug connected to a three-core cable. The three wires of the three-core cable have different coloured coverings. State the colour of the covering of the neutral wire.
Which two parts of a three-pin plug protect the wiring of a circuit?
Some electrical appliances are connected to the mains supply using a two-core cable. Appliances that are double insulated do not require all three wires. What does 'double insulated' mean?
acceptedAnswers: case is not made of metal
markScheme: 1 mark: The **case** is made of a **non-metal** / non-conducting material / plastic / insulator

parts.text: Appliances that are double insulated do not require all three wires. State which of the three wires is not required.
An electrical appliance is connected to a 20 V supply. The current in the appliance is 3 A. Calculate the power of the appliance.
Another electrical appliance is connected to a 20 V supply. The appliance transfers 300 J of energy. Calculate the charge. Give the unit.

questions.title: Radio power supply and circuit protection
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: Figure 1 shows a radio. The radio can be powered by connecting the two-core cable to the mains electricity supply. What must be fitted to the cable before it can be connected to the mains electricity supply?
The radio's cable has only two wires inside. What are the names of the two wires?
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: C - Live and neutral

parts.text: Complete the sentence. Choose the correct answer from the box.
segments: It is safe to connect the radio to the mains electricity supply using a two-core cable because the radio is

parts.text: The radio can also be powered by a battery. What type of current does a battery supply?
markScheme: 1 mark: Answer: B - Direct current (d.c.) only

parts.text: Figure 2 shows a fuse and a circuit breaker. Fuses and circuit breakers are able to disconnect and switch off circuits. Complete the sentence. Choose the correct answer from the box.
segments: A fuse or a circuit breaker is connected to the

parts.text: What happens to cause a fuse or circuit breaker to disconnect a circuit?
markScheme: 1 mark: Too great a **current** flows / a **surge** of current / an electrical **fault**

parts.text: Suggest two advantages of using a circuit breaker to disconnect a circuit compared with using a fuse.
markScheme: 1 mark: Can be **reset** / does not need replacing

parts.text: An RCD adaptor is an automatic safety switch that is recommended for use with an electric lawnmower. Suggest two reasons why there is a particular risk of an electric shock when using an electric lawnmower.
markScheme: 1 mark: Risk of **cutting** through the **cable** / wire
1 mark: The **grass** may be **wet** / it may rain / risk of touching **exposed** parts

parts.text: If something goes wrong with an electric lawnmower, there will be a difference between the current in the live wire and the current in the neutral wire. Why will there be a difference?
markScheme: 1 mark: Some current will flow through the lawnmower / user / to **earth**

parts.text: Use the words charge, current and time to write an equation which shows the relationship between them.
markScheme: 1 mark: **charge = current × time** / $Q = I \times t$ (or any correct rearrangement)

parts.text: Calculate how much charge flows when a current of 30 milliamps passes for 40 milliseconds. Give the unit.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct unit conversions: 30 milliamps = **0.03 A** and 40 milliseconds = **0.04 s**
1 mark: Correct final answer: **0.0012 C** (coulombs) (accept 1200 μC or 1.2 mC)

questions.title: Adaptor, appliance currents and electrical safety
questions.subject: physics

parts.text: An adaptor can be used to connect up to four appliances in parallel to one 230 V mains socket. The adaptor is fitted with a 13 A fuse. Table 1 shows the current each appliance draws. What current will flow to the adaptor when the television, computer and hairdryer are plugged into the adaptor?
Write down the equation which links current, electrical power and voltage.
Calculate the electrical power used when the television (2 A), computer (1 A) and hairdryer (4 A) are plugged into the 230 V adaptor. Give the unit.

The adaptor is fitted with a 13 A fuse. The television (2 A), computer (1 A) and hairdryer (4 A) are already plugged in. What would happen to the fuse if the heater (8 A) is also plugged into the adaptor? Give a reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: The fuse **melts** / blows / burns out / breaks
1 mark: The total current would be **15 A**, which is greater than the **13 A** fuse rating

parts.text: The diagram shows two of the appliances. For safety reasons, it is important that the iron has an earth wire connected to its outer metal case. Explain why.
markScheme: 1 mark: If the **live wire** touches the metal **case** / the case becomes live
1 mark: Current flows to **earth** (through the earth wire) / the **fuse** melts, disconnecting the circuit

parts.text: A hairdryer does not have an earth wire. It is safe to use because it is double insulated. Explain what the term double insulated means.
markScheme: 1 mark: The outer **case** is made of an **insulator** / plastic / not made of metal

parts.text: The diagram shows the structure of a cable. The cable is part of an undersoil heating circuit inside a large greenhouse. The cable is connected to the mains electricity supply through a residual current circuit breaker. What is the frequency of the mains electricity supply in the UK?

The cable is connected to the mains supply through a residual current circuit breaker (RCCB). If the cable is accidentally cut, the circuit breaker automatically switches the circuit off. What happens, as the cable is cut, to cause the circuit breaker to switch the circuit off?
markScheme: 1 mark: Some **current** flows to **earth** / through the earth wire / copper braid
1 mark: The RCCB detects a **difference** between the current in the **live** and **neutral** wire

parts.text: A circuit can also be switched off by the action of a fuse. Give one advantage of using a circuit breaker to switch off a circuit rather than a fuse.
markScheme: 1 mark: Can be **reset** / does not need replacing / **faster** acting

parts.text: The 230 volt mains electricity supply causes a current of 11 amps to flow through the cable. Calculate the amount of charge that flows through the cable when the cable is switched on for 2 hours. Give the unit.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct unit conversion: 2 hours = **7200 s**

parts.text: The 230 volt mains electricity supply causes a current of 11 amps to flow through the undersoil heating cable. Calculate the energy transferred from the cable to the soil in 2 hours.
markScheme: 1 mark: Correct final answer: **18 216 000 J** (accept 18 216 kJ or 18.216 MJ)

parts.text: The heating circuit includes a thermistor buried in the soil, which acts as a thermostat to control the temperature of the soil. Describe how an increase in the temperature of the soil affects the thermistor.
